body: openjdk6 passed this time, maybe the old saying is true: third time's the charm
one question, @sprsquish , it seems zipkin/sbt set -XX:MaxPermSize=1024m but Travis doesn't use it so the the MaxPermSize is 512M for ci build, that's probably the reason.
@hunglin good catch. I'll see if I can get Travis to use our script instead.

it passed!

Sorry to be confused...
I will be glad if you pull this!
After a lengthy debugging session I realized this doesn't work for `zipkin-web` as the application fails to load the required resources. The `package-dist` method seems to work.
I suspect that the problem is that far-jarring screws up the META-INF files.  You could try to convince sbt-assembly to concatenate the META-INF files instead of obliterating the extras.

Here's the output of `./bin/sbt --debug assembly 2>/dev/null | ag Merging | ag META-INF`:

```
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/MANIFEST.MF' with strategy 'discard'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/DEPENDENCIES' with strategy 'discard'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/MANIFEST.MF' with strategy 'discard'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/DEPENDENCIES' with strategy 'discard'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/services/com.twitter.finagle.Announcer' with strategy 'filterDistinctLines'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/services/com.twitter.finagle.Resolver' with strategy 'filterDistinctLines'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/services/javax.ws.rs.ext.MessageBodyWriter' with strategy 'first'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/MANIFEST.MF' with strategy 'discard'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/DEPENDENCIES' with strategy 'discard'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/INDEX.LIST' with strategy 'discard'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/services/javax.ws.rs.ext.MessageBodyReader' with strategy 'first'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/MANIFEST.MF' with strategy 'discard'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/DEPENDENCIES' with strategy 'discard'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/services/com.twitter.finagle.Announcer' with strategy 'filterDistinctLines'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/services/com.twitter.finagle.Resolver' with strategy 'filterDistinctLines'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/services/javax.ws.rs.ext.MessageBodyWriter' with strategy 'first'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/MANIFEST.MF' with strategy 'discard'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/DEPENDENCIES' with strategy 'discard'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/services/com.twitter.finagle.Announcer' with strategy 'first'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/INDEX.LIST' with strategy 'discard'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/services/com.twitter.finagle.Resolver' with strategy 'first'
[warn] Merging 'META-INF/services/javax.ws.rs.ext.MessageBodyReader' with strategy 'first'
```

I don't see anything that may be related to resources, but
- I may have messed up and didn't find all merges, I don't use `sbt` daily
- an interesting line may be in there, I just don't recognize it

Does anything stand out to you?

My gut feeling is that https://github.com/twitter/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-web/src/main/scala/com/twitter/zipkin/web/Main.scala#L54 and https://github.com/twitter/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-web/src/main/scala/com/twitter/zipkin/web/Handlers.scala#L191-L200 don't agree with assembly on where the resources should be. I tried passing in `-zipkin.web.resourcesRoot='/'` (since the resources are in the root of the fat-jar), which did nothing, so either I'm on the wrong track, or I messed up the fix.
with strategy "first" is probably wrong.  You probably want to merge with strategy "concat" if it's possible.

Might be better altogether to switch to sbt-onejar: https://github.com/sbt/sbt-onejar

It wont create an uber jar of all classes, rather package the project into a single jar along with its libraries thus eliminating the conflicts.

sbt-assembly already has special handling for stuff under META-INF: https://github.com/sbt/sbt-assembly/blob/0.9.2/src/main/scala/sbtassembly/Plugin.scala#L347-L360

I tried to change from discard to concat on manifest.mf, but then the build fails with `java.util.zip.ZipException: duplicate entry: META-INF/MANIFEST.MF` (which is pretty strange btw).

I feel this is starting to take more effort than what a fat jar is worth; the package-dist method is safe and stable. I'm completely open to trying out anything you guys come up with, but I don't plan to investigate this further.
I encounter this error too.
Just to check this off the list, have you done a clean compile?

Looking forward to this one!

@tdrisdelle Are you using HBase? We are using HBase as span storage in our production. And annotation search didn't work until this patch.  It seems that a wrong query is thrown into HBase. The reason is that  `bb` is array backed `ByteBuffer`, then `bb.array()` returns whole of backed array.

I'm sorry for the confusion.... what I meant was "I've checked out this patch and tested it on my local build with my own HBase back end and now it works fine, why isn't it being merged?"

Thanks for providing the patch.
Thank you for your test!
@sprsquish @johnynek Have you had time to review this? Is there something that has to be fixed in this PR? Or is it something that you will end up not merging eventually?
I agree with eirslett, I'd think this is a valuable change that should be merged.

Duplicate of one that I raised:
https://github.com/twitter/zipkin/issues/403

because the project depends on two different version com.twitter.common.zookeeper.group(0.0.44&0.0.67).

but they have different signature:
0.0.44:
public final void watch(final GroupChangeListener groupChangeListener)
      throws WatchException, InterruptedException {

0.0.67:
public final Command watch(final GroupChangeListener groupChangeListener)
      throws WatchException, InterruptedException {

and your compile error shows that it need 0.0.44(void return value),so failed.
[error] java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: com.twitter.common.zookeeper.Group.watch(Lcom/twitter/common/zookeeper/Group$GroupChangeListener;)V

look at the (V) of end of the line, it needs void return version watch method.

so when you remove dependency of 0.0.67, it works.
as a way to test the problem,just change the followwing ivy files to group 0.0.44 from 0.0.67:
~/.ivy2/cache/com.twitter/util-zk-common_2.9.2/ivy-6.16.0.xml
~/.ivy2/cache/com.twitter.common.zookeeper/server-set/ivy-1.0.72.xml

hopes this will be useful and you admin can fix it:)

@eirslett I just pushed a bunch of changes that bring the OSS version of Zipkin in line with our internal version. On top of which, I've updated our sync tools so we'll start to schedule our syncs with the other Twitter libraries (once a week). 

The TravisCI integration has also been fixed and should now be trustworthy.

The biggest change is probably that we've moved to scala 2.10.4 and we're more closely tracking the core Twitter libraries.

Please merge master and we'll take a look and get this merged in.

Thanks again for all your work.

Ok, I rebased it against master, but unfortunately, with the latest changes, the tests fail :-(
Could you please help me out a bit, if you see what the problem is?
@eirslett looks like you got it fixed! I'll pull this internally and we'll have a look.

Sweet!

Style issue: we use two spaces for indentation.

Is there a way to populate some example data so someone could see an example of this in action?
good!

If you want to populate test data:

1) Configure a local Zipkin instance running on Cassandra
2) Run zipkin-tracegen
3) Run the hadoop job
4) Look at the web UI - traces should now be generated.

Alternatively: I'll see if I can make a modified JSON dump of our production data and host it somewhere as a static page.
OK, I (think) I fixed the indentation now.

Ok, I guess it's cumbersome to set up hadoop and everything just for some sample data, so here's an alternative.
1) Start Zipkin with a local MySQL instance
2) Dump this into the database: https://gist.github.com/eirslett/302b070cf6bff9598420
3) You're ready to go!
Great. Anyway to get this into the zipkin-example project? It's already possible to boot it up with the right flags set to populate it with example data. This could piggyback on that.

Yes, it would definitely be nice to dump that test data into the example project.
But I'm not quite sure how to solve the dependency links between modules: zipkin-anormdb probably shouldn't know about test data, since that's only relevant for zipkin-example. But AnormSpanStore doesn't expose a public API with "importSql" functionality, and I don't think it should? So how should we dump the data into Anorm? (Or, eventually, should we break any of the dependency barriers I mentioned?)
Hrm. Eventually we'll need some sort of API for this. For now, maybe just put the data in zipkin-tracegen along with some documentation on what to do with it.

com.twitter.zipkin.storage.Aggregates. has a storeDependencies method. I could hardcode the test data in a AggregateTestData Scala object and put that either in zipkin-example or zipkin-tracegen? Then the test data should also work independent of which database backend you're using.
I commited the SQL test dump into zipkin-tracegen for now, let me know if you want me to convert it to a Scala dump!
Okay. Pulled internally.
Do you guys think we could merge this branch?  I have some code based on this which allows the zipkin-tracer to use kafka.
LGTM, but I don't know ruby very well.  @jamescway have you reviewed this code?  Does it look good to you?
@mosesn yea LGTM :+1:

Hi, I have some idea, can you judge it?
- I assume that IPv4 addresses are just being stored in Zipkin DB without any interpretation, indexing or using as keys, right? 
- make sure instrumentation does not break while working on pure IPv6 hosts. Just to store 0.0.0.0 as IPv4 in this case
- add extra default annotation like this "ipv6"="1a02:3b8::402:7a31:c2ff:fef2:b61d" for span at server side
- - tweak Web UI to do not show 0.0.0.0 as IP

Another useful step:
- \* add two annotations like "remotehost" = "myservice.mydomain.com" and "localhost" = "myservice-345-23-node.mydomain.com" to see the names outside and inside SLB.

What do you think? Will it significantly increase the amount of data? Do you have any proposal of how to do it more naturally?
I haven't tried the Kafka receiver, does that not work?
But no, there's no plans at twitter to replace scribe.

sorry - even like this it does not fully work. Will submit a PR again when I got everything working.

I'm late here, but I think it should be possible to replace scribe with fluentd: https://github.com/fluent/fluentd
Fluentd comes with a Scribe plugin, so you wouldn't need to make any changes to the Zipkin source code.
It's also possible to set up fluentd with secure forwarding, so you could potentially ship your trace data to a public cloud, different from where you're running your application, and then run Zipkin there.
